ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PRIMARY SCHOOLS IN TELOK BLANGAH
(Construction)


    1. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (i) what is the progress of the construction of the proposed two primary schools in Telok Blangah; (ii) what will be the facilities available; (iii) when they will be operational; and (iv) is there any deviation from the original plans and, if so, what and why.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Education (Mr Ho Kah Leong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to reply.

    Construction of the new primary school at the junction of Telok Blangah Road and Golf Club Road in Telok Blangah Constituency is in progress and the school is expected to be completed in April 1984.

Column: 334



    However, works for the second new primary school at Telok Blangah Drive in Telok Blangah Constituency have not been started pending the decision on whether schools in Singapore should go full-day or remain as two-session schools.

    The new primary school being built in Telok Blangah Constituency is of 1980 model. It will have the following standard facilities:-

    (a) 36 classrooms;

    (b) three second-language rooms, two art and craft rooms, two audio-visual aid rooms, two music rooms and one science room;

    (c) a library, hall, canteen, sick bay, dental clinic, bookshop, kitchenette, two extra-curricular activities rooms and three store-rooms;

    (d) a football field, basketball court and volleyball court; and

    (e) administrative offices including Principal's and Vice-Principal's rooms, staff lounge and staff room.

Column: 335



     Mr Rohan bin Kamis (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, when will this decision be made so that work can start for the second primary school in my Constituency?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir, work will start as soon as a decision is reached that schools in Singapore should go full-day.

EDUCATION OF HANDICAPPED CHILDREN


    2. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education why his Ministry is not willing to shoulder the responsibility of educating our handicapped children like the deaf, the blind and the retarded and whether such a move will deprive them of the best education possible.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    Far from being unwilling to shoulder the responsibility, the Government has and will continue to give substantial assistance to voluntary organizations in the education of handicapped children. The Government's policy is to encourage the efforts of the voluntary organizations which are running the special schools and to support them wherever possible. The Ministry of Education has been providing teachers to teach in the eight special schools. Similarly, the Ministry of Social Affairs has been providing instructors for the School for the Blind and the School for the Deaf. In addition, the Ministries of Social Affairs and Health give annual grants to the special schools to meet part of their recurrent expenditure.

    In 1982, 69 government teachers and 11 instructors were sent to the special schools. The Ministry of Education had also agreed to deploy another 25 teachers to the special schools last year. The total government subsidy per pupil in the special schools taking into account the grants provided, the teachers and instructors provided was $1,626 per pupil in 1982. This is 41% more than the subsidy of $1,153 per pupil in our regular primary schools in 1982.

Column: 336



    In terms of physical facilities, two school buildings have been made available to the special schools at nominal rental. The Ministry is also assisting the Singapore Association for Retarded Children to take over the Griffiths School building for the Association's use on a nominal rental basis.

    Some handicapped children with normal intelligence attend regular schools at both primary and secondary levels. There are nine visually-handicapped pupils and 59 pupils with hearing impairment studying in our regular primary schools. At the secondary level, 36 visually-handicapped students are studying in seven regular secondary schools and 63 students with hearing impairment in two regular secondary schools. Six resource teachers are provided to assist these students. The students attend regular classes with normal students and follow the normal curriculum. They are given special assistance when needed by the resource teachers.

    At the request of the associations, the Institute of Education is planning to run training courses for special education teachers. The details are still being discussed by the Institute and, the associations. The course is likely to be a 3-year part-time course leading to the Certificate in Special Education.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether his Ministry will eventually take over the education of handicapped children, thereby leaving the associations to look after the other areas of care, like counselling, home support, rehabilitation, etc.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, at present the Government has no intention of taking over the special schools. The reason is as follows. Special schools are run by voluntary groups comprising interested and dedicated persons. These schools have special and unique needs, including counselling needs, which the Member described just now. These special needs are quite different, in the curriculum, and in the kind of attention they need, from our regular normal schools. Their management committees are able to look into these needs and provide personal attention in a way which no administrators in a

Column: 337

bureaucracy can really do. Therefore, instead of taking them over, we believe that it is in the best interest of the special schools to be independent and autonomous. The Ministry on the other hand can and will continue to provide them with financial support and manpower, wherever possible.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I understand the hon. Minister of State, his Ministry, far from refusing to shoulder the responsibility, is doing all it can. But there was a statement, not very long ago, from the Chairman of the Singapore Association for the Deaf (this was reproduced in the Straits Times from its News Letter). The Chairman is on record as saying that the Ministry of Education has said that it is not the responsibility of the Ministry of Education to provide teachers for the Association's schools. Would the Minister care to comment on this, and may I know also from the Minister whether his Ministry is providing trained teachers for the classes run by the Singapore Association for the Deaf?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon : Mr Speaker, Sir, the Chairman of the Association for the Deaf is entitled to his views. As far as providing trained teachers to help in the School for the Deaf, we are indeed providing teachers for the School for the Deaf.

SKILLS DEVELOPMENT FUND
(Particulars)


    3. Dr Toh Chin Chye asked the Minister for Finance, up to 31st December, 1982, (a) how much was collected for the Skills Development Fund; and (b) how much has been disbursed for the purpose of the fund and to which organizations and companies.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 31st December, 1982, a total amount of S$313.8 million was collected for the Skills Development Fund.

    A total of S$27.5 million has been disbursed as at 31st December, 1982, under the three grant schemes of the Fund. In the

Column: 338

private sector, 1,288 companies received S$18.8 million in training grants, 96 received S$2.0 million in interest grants for mechanization and 23 received S$0.6 million in development consultancy grants. Government ministries and statutory boards received S$6.0 million in training grants and S$O.1 million in development consultancy grants.

    The following organizations in the private sector have benefitted from disbursements from the Fund--

                    Companies

Insurance               316           22.5%

Transportation           94            6.7%

    As at 31st December, 1982, a further sum of S$102.4 million remained to be paid under the three schemes. Of this sum, S$78.9 million is payable under the Training Grant Scheme, S$19.8 million under the Interest Grants for Mechanization Scheme and S$3.7 million under the Development Consultancy Scheme.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye (Rochore): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Act provides for equipment subsidies and the Minister answered just now that subsidies were given in order to permit some companies to mechanize. I would like to question why should one company's contribution be used to subsidize the capital assets of another company?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I think the purpose of the Skills Development Fund is to improve skills, and the increase in skills and in productivity is usually accompanied by an improvement in methods which include mechanization. In order that we can improve skills in procedures which require mechanization, we have sometimes to encourage companies to mechanize and the amounts which have been given have not been very considerable and are amply justified.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I draw the attention of the Minister for

Column: 339

Finance that payroll tax has increased by 216% over a period of five years. Contributions to the CPF have increased by 289% in five years. I dread how fast the Skills Development tax will add up to the cost of labour. It is inevitable that in the payment of these levies altogether the cost of labour would be pushed upwards, and this will make exports less competitive.

    Will the Minister agree that the Skills Development levy does not seem to completely fulfil the original intention and whether he will consider suspending the Skills Development tax until such period when the Singapore economy is on the boom again?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I do not want to go into the cost of labour and its effect on the economy. This is given in statistics in the Economic Survey and can be looked at.

    Payroll tax, as far as I am concerned, is not related to the Skills Development Fund. It is a revenue tax which was imposed first during the Malaysian period and which I found very convenient for financing of other Singapore Government projects. So I do not include payroll tax in the cost of labour. It may be considered as a revenue item.

    The Skills Development Fund has been set up specially to increase the productivity of workers, and the amounts which have been disbursed are increasing and will eventually increase to meet the contributions which are being made by the companies. I certainly hope this will come about very soon and I hope that productivity will increase accordingly.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that in spite of the Skills Development tax and in spite of the efforts of the Productivity Board in organizing courses, the productivity of Singapore labour has fallen down to 2.2%?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Again, Mr Speaker, Sir, I think he had better study the Economic Survey for he will find that the reason why productivity has fallen is due perhaps to the present economic situation where a lot of workers are retained, even on short-time, and therefore the figures on productivity are affected by the fact that a lot of additional labour is retained. I do not think

Column: 340

this is related so much to the Skills Development Fund. It would be very surprising if all the training that we have done under the Skills Development Fund that this has been the cause of productivity falling.

EXPENDITURE ON MANPOWER
(1980-82)

HAWKER LICENCES
(Criteria)


    5. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for the Environment whether his Ministry will consider the issuing of hawker licences on the basis of culinary skills instead of the present criteria of hardship and age limit.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry does not issue any more new licences for people to operate in Government or Statutory Boards' food centres, except to a few who are in financial hardship and unable to take up other gainful employment. Vacant stalls in these food centres are reserved for the resettlement of street hawkers. There are still some 2,300 street hawkers comprising 1,450 cooked food, 310 market produce and 540 piece and sundry goods hawkers who must be resettled into proper premises for environmental and public health reasons.

    The policy to resite all street hawkers into proper premises was implemented in 1970. All new markets and food centres built by the Ministry of the Environment (MOE) and HDB are reserved for this purpose. The HDB also reserved some stalls in its markets and food centres to resettle shopkeepers and farmers in lieu of alternative premises or cash compensation. Some 23,200 street hawkers have been resited since 1970.

    With the completion of the cooked food centres at Kreta Ayer, Church Street, Amoy Street and Hill Street, another 1,170 street

Column: 342

hawkers will be resited, leaving a balance of 1,130 hawkers on the street. As land will not be made available for the construction of cooked food centres in the central business core areas, alternative means will have to be found to resite these hawkers. My Ministry and the Ministry of National Development will be looking into various alternatives, including the conversion of vacant market produce stalls in existing MOE and HDB markets into cooked food stalls.

    Our priority, therefore, is in the resiting of street hawkers into the limited number of existing stalls. We are aware though of the growing tendency amongst the public to patronize stalls with accomplished culinary skills to the extent that people travel long distances to patronize their favourite food centres. Today, the business of selling cooked food is no longer a means to eke out a livelihood, but it is a business as lucrative as any other for those with special culinary skills. We see culinary skills as our heritage. However, in view of the priority we have to give to the resiting of street hawkers, the question of issuing more licences based on culinary skills would have to be considered later. Meanwhile, those with culinary skills and who wish to sell cooked food can rent a stall in a coffee shop or other private food establishments.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister what is the policy of his Ministry as regards the location of these street hawkers which, he says, is their first priority? Is it the policy of the Ministry to try and site them as near as possible to where they have been carrying on their street hawking trades, or is it the policy to send them out into the new towns?

     Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the present policy is to resite the street hawkers in the nearest food centre available.

TAXIS
(Shortage during Chinese New Year holidays)


    6. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour whether he is aware that only a few taxis were on the road on Chinese New Year and that some of them even failed to stop when flagged down and if he will look into the matter.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry is aware that there were fewer taxis plying on the road during the last Chinese New Year holidays. This artificial shortage is not unexpected as 96% of our 10,714 taxis are owned by individuals and 82% of the 32,275 taxi drivers are Chinese. Like other Chinese, they would like to celebrate this special festive season with their families and visiting relatives. My Ministry has, however, ensured that adequate bus services were provided and charging the usual bus fares during the festive season.

    A proposal to allow taxi drivers to levy a $1 surcharge during the Chinese New Year holidays is being considered by the Taxi Advisory Committee. However, this proposal requires careful study as it may set a precedent for requests of surcharges on other festive occasions. Besides, the $1 surcharge may not solve the taxi shortage problem during the Chinese New Year holidays.

    The Hon. Member has also mentioned that some taxis failed to stop when flagged. ROV receives such complaints from time to time. Taxi drivers are obliged to stop when flagged unless they have passengers in their taxis or a 'NOT FOR HIRE' sign has been displayed. However, sometimes taxi drivers did not stop because they did not notice that there were commuters by the roadside flagging for their taxis as they need also to pay attention to traffic conditions on the road. Therefore, complaints of this nature need to be carefully investigated by ROV.

BUILDING CONSTRUCTION AND
SHIPBUILDING INDUSTRIES
(Steps to reduce accidents)


    8. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour what steps are being taken to reduce the number of accidents in the building construction and shipbuilding industries which showed an increase during the year 1982.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the accident statistics (Cols. 433 - 434) for the construction and shipbuilding and repairing industries for 1981 and 1982 are as follows:
statistics - ACCIDENT STATISTICS FOR CONSTRUCTION AND SHIPBUILDING INDUSTRY (Cols. 433 - 434)


    In the construction industry, the number of accidents increased from 1,073 in 1981 to 1,460 in 1982, an increase of 36%. The number of deaths increased from 28 in 1981 to 49 in 1982, an increase of 75%.

    In the shipbuilding and repairing industry, there were 1,274 accidents in 1982. This is only six cases more than the number in 1981. The number of fatal accidents has however fallen dramatically from 24 in 1981 to nine in 1982, a decrease of 62%.

    The construction and shipbuilding and repairing industries are two of the most hazardous industries. Not surprisingly, our citizens shun employment in these two

Column: 345

The Economy in 1982

    A detailed review of the performance of our economy in 1982 can be found in the Economic Survey of Singapore, 1982 (Cols. 447 - 728), copies of which have been given to hon. Members of the House earlier. Today I shall highlight our performance briefly.

    In my Budget Statement last year, I told the House that I expected 1982 to be a grim year with mounting problems of unemployment and protectionism in the industrialized countries. To my regret, my fears have turned out to be well-founded. The world economy is today in a most perilous state. The hopes of many finance ministers, bankers and economists were dashed when the US economy did not recover and consequently failed to pull the world out of the recession. Instead, the US economy contracted by 1.8%. Growth in the other industrialized countries, where it did occur, was muted. As a result, more workers in the industrialized countries lost their jobs, causing the already high unemployment to scale to new peaks. In the United States, the number of people who

In November last year Trade Ministers from 88 countries attended a meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in an attempt to halt and to roll back protectionism. The prolonged world recession has caused many countries to turn desperately to short-term and politically popular measures to safeguard employment. NATION-WIDE POWER FAILURE ON 5TH FEBRUARY, 1983


    17. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what cause or causes led to the major nation-wide power failure on Saturday, 5th February, 1983; and (b) what steps will be taken to prevent a similar occurrence in the future.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: I would like to take advantage of this question to explain not only what caused the island-wide power failure on Saturday, 5th February, 1983, but also why it took many hours to restore full supply, and finally what we can do to minimize disruption and danger to life in the event of a power failure.

    The power failure on 5th February, 1983, occurred as a result of a severe short circuit at a new section of the 230 kilovolt switchboard being installed and tested at Senoko Power Station Stage III which is under construction.

    The short circuit was so severe that it created a surge of power equivalent to five times the power being generated to supply the entire Republic at that time. The extreme overload severely disturbed the electricity supply system and led to the tripping (automatic disconnection from the system) in rapid succession of the generators at Jurong, Senoko and Pasir Panjang Power Stations. All the power stations were affected because they are interlinked through the Republic's electricity supply network.

Column: 437



    The power failure did not occur because of insufficient generating capacity. At present, the daily peak demand for electricity is about 1,350 MW but the total generating capacity of all the power stations is about 2,100 MW. There is therefore more than sufficient generating capacity to cater for Singapore's demand.

    Let me now explain our electricity supply system and why it took several hours to restore full supply to the island. In a power station fuel is burned in the boilers which produce high pressure steam. This steam is used to drive the turbine-generators to generate electricity. Electricity generated at power stations is fed to four major 230 kilovolt substations through the 230 kilovolt cable transmission system. From there, electricity is distributed to consumers via some 3,600 substations and more than 33,000 km of their associated cable systems. This system of inter-linking power stations and substations through cables constitutes our electricity supply network.

    Like all major electricity supply systems, Singapore's power stations are linked through the network. This has been found by practice to be the most efficient and economical mode of operation and affords flexibility and reliability. During a planned shutdown for overhaul and maintenance of equipment at one power station, electricity can be supplied from the other power stations. More important, if there is a fault in one power station causing a generator to trip, the other power stations with reserve capacity (or, in technical jargon, spinning reserve) will automatically take over the load thereby preventing power failure.

    There is, however, an attendant disadvantage in such a system in that an extraordinary fault at one power station may affect the other power stations by virtue of the fact that they are linked. On 5th February, 1983, such an extraordinary fault occurred, causing such a severe overload that it tripped out all the generators in operation within seconds, nullifying the back-up system of spinning reserve.

    When there is a total collapse of the electricity supply system, restoration of supply takes time because established safety procedures have to be followed. When the generators trip, the boilers go out and the fuel pipes to the boiler have to be shut down. The furnaces then have to be cleared of remnant oil vapour otherwise the boilers may explode on ignition.

    Once the boilers have been started, it takes time to build up high pressure steam. The turbine-generators have to be run-up slowly and it takes about an hour before the generator can transmit any electricity into the system. There are technical and practical limitations to the speed at which the boilers and the turbine-generators can be loaded. This is a slow process because fast loading will damage the turbine-generators. The speed at which supplies are restored has also to be balanced with the rate of generation, otherwise the system might collapse again. That is why restoration of supply could only be started three hours after the system collapsed on 5th February, 1983.

    This procedure of restarting the electricity supply system is universally followed by all utility authorities irrespective of the type of generator or boiler in use.

    Can we prevent a recurrence of the particular fault that led to the island-wide power failure on 5th February, 1983? The answer is obviously yes. We can tighten up the precautions to be taken prior to carrying out testing of new high voltage equipment in the electricity supply system. This is being done by the PUB.

    Can we ensure that we will never ever have an island-wide power failure? The answer, both theoretically and practically, is No - so long as our power stations are interlinked with automatic transfer of load from one station to another as the need arises.

    Why, then, do we not change our system and instead have each power station service a separate, self-contained sub-network? The reason is because such a system has its own grave disadvantages. If a fault develops at one of the power stations, electricity would not be supplied automatically from another power station and the net result is that area blackouts would be more frequent and more prolonged.

Column: 439



    In 1981 and 1982, there were 77 occasions when one or more generators in our three power stations tripped. However, because our power stations are linked in a network, the other generators were able to pick up the load and only on seven occasions were there power failures covering large parts of the Republic. In other words, the interlinking of the three power stations prevented 7O major power failures. This would not have been possible if the three power stations were not interlinked.

    Furthermore, if the stations were not linked the generating capacity of each power station would have to be increased to even out the load if a particular generator in the power station was malfunctioning. This means higher costs and therefore higher electricity tariffs.

    In a linked network system the generating capacity of the power stations are, in effect, pooled thus allowing economical operation since the more efficient generators can be used to supply a large percentage of the total load.

    Taking all things into consideration the PUB, in common with all major electricity supply systems in the world, has decided that the linked network system is superior and, considering that the last island-wide power failure occurred 17 years ago in 1965, I think that the decision is correct.

    Finally, what can we do to minimize disruption and danger to life in the event of power failures? First, we can and we have installed standby generators in essential service installations such as waterworks, gasworks, hospitals and the airports. These standby generators can be started up during power failures. Secondly, high-rise public and commercial buildings, shopping complexes and hotels are required, under the Building Control Regulations, to instal standby generators, which, during a power failure, will automatically be started up to bring all the lifts down to the first storey and open the doors. The standby generators also operate the fireman's lift, fire-fighting facilities and emergency lighting in the building. Thirdly, industries, commercial and other organizations which, because of the nature of their business, cannot tolerate power failures, should likewise instal standby generators. However, all standby systems must be properly maintained and serviced regularly so that they will work during emergencies.

I am happy to note that HDB has taken the lead to instal automatic rescue devices to bring lifts down to the nearest floor and open automatically in the event of a power failure. HDB has 5,559 lifts in their estates and they have installed these automatic rescue devices in about 5,400. The remaining 159 lifts are old and HDB intends to replace them.
